item.title: Comment by Adrian Lester+00:00
item.description:
I think you hit a big issue the head, Martin!
It seems to me that the main thing a manager of a software team needs to be focusing on is people - personalities, relationships within the team, between teams, etc. Projects don't often fail because of a technical issue. It tends to be "politics" that scuppers projects, and when people say politics they really mean people issues.
In my experience large companies don't seem to get this point. Manager training tends to be things like "Risk & Issue Management" and "Metrics". Spreadsheets will save the day! I end up spending most of my time clearing corporate crud out of the way to let my developers get on with their job of developing. It's what drove me into management in the first place.
On your point about competition - I haven't got an answer yet either. Competition is a very strong motivator, especially for men and the reality is that the software development industry is predominatly male. We can't help but compete. Why do you think someone came up with metrics in the first place?
